awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Integrative Physiology of Anoxia Tolerance in Turtles
awd_abstract_narration: All animals are subject to environmental stress during their lives and oxygen availability may be a particular problem for animals in aquatic habitats, where solubility is low and competition for it is high. One animal, the Western painted turtle has evolved the capacity to survive complete oxygen deprivation, also called anoxia, for over 30 hours at 20°C and for more than three months at 3°C, which is longer than any other tetrapod. This ability allows the painted turtle to overwinter in oxygen-depleted, ice-covered ponds in the wild. To understand the underlying mechanisms, this research uses the recently sequenced painted turtle genome to determine the gene expression changes that occur during anoxia and to relate them to the physiological changes that are already known to occur. It focuses on the turtle's heart, which, in other vertebrates, is extremely sensitive to oxygen deprivation, including humans. It also focuses on development, because hatchling turtles are less tolerant of anoxia than adults. This research also explores processes related to the handling of the massive lactic acid loads, which accumulate to levels higher than seen in any other animal. This includes studies of how lactic acid affects the turtle shell and heart and how that lactic acid metabolized by the body. There is also educational component involving the St. Louis Zoo, which will enhance one of its existing educational apprenticeship program representing mostly underserved and underrepresented minorities.  It also supports an annual workshop to promote civic science, which will provide resources and opportunities for St. Louis area scientists to connect with high school and college students looking to gain scientific research experience. The broader impacts of this project will be to provide important insights into an economically, ecologically, and clinically relevant problem, namely why some animals are more tolerant of oxygen deprivation than others. It will also increase student participation in the sciences, generally, and comparative animal physiology, specifically.

por.por_cntn:
Oxygen deprivation is an economically, ecologically, and clinically relevant problem and understanding why some animals are more tolerant of it than others can yield important clues to minimize its destructive effects in biological systems. One animal, the Western painted turtle can survive complete oxygen deprivation (also called anoxia) for over 30 hours at 20?C and for more than 170 days at 3?C, longer than any other tetrapod. This ability enables it to naturally overwinter in oxygen-depleted, ice-locked ponds within the northern portion of its geographic range. Our work improved our understanding of the molecular and physiological mechanisms of anoxia tolerance in this species, especially in turtle's heart and shell.

The sequencing of the painted turtle?s genome in 2013 enabled us to study the entire transcriptome of the heart with both acclimation to the cold and anoxia in hatchling and adult turtles. Hatchling turtles are much less tolerant of anoxia than adults, so comparing the two enabled us to learn which genes may be required for anoxia tolerance. This comparative approach yielded many findings, the most important of which is that hatchlings have extremely high expression levels of proteins associated with ribosomes, the organelle that makes new proteins. We later followed up with a study of thousands of proteins and found linearity between the two. We hypothesize that the differing anoxia tolerances between the two life stages may be related to the hatchling?s inability to shutdown protein synthesis as part of the metabolic suppression response.

We carried out two studies of cardiac function in turtles that produced evidence to support our theory for the mechanism of cardiac functional suppression, which is a requirement for anoxia tolerance. First, we quantified the ability of isolated cardiac cells from turtles to prevent changes in acidity during anoxia and found it to be half that of mammals. This means that a small amount of lactic acid, which is produced during anoxia, will quickly acidify the heart. In a later study, we found that the turtle heart?s contractile machinery is easily inhibited by this acidification. Taken together, we believe an important mechanism for cardiac functional suppression during anoxia is rapid inhibition of the machinery caused by a sudden increase in the acidity. This differs from mammalian heart, which can accumulate a large amount of lactic acid without showing inhibition which, under anoxic conditions, would be fatal to the organ.

Our studies also examined the role of the turtle shell during anoxia, which is known to be an important source of buffer to prevent the animal?s pH from falling to deadly levels despite the accumulation of lactic acid to six times the lethal level to humans. This buffering is achieved through the utilization of carbonates in the shell and skeleton and through the uptake of the lactic acid into the mineral. In one experiment, we studied whether there was a trade-off between the ability of the shell to prevent acidification of the body fluids and its ability to afford physical protection for the animal. We found that the strength of the shell was maintained throughout the period of anoxia and only failed at the time that the other organ systems in the turtle also began to fail. The turtle?s shell did become softer with time under water, with or without oxygen, but this was more likely related to the accumulation of water in the bone. To understand where the carbonate used for buffering originated, we used several spectroscopic techniques, including Raman and FTIR, to quantify different types of carbonate with the turtle?s shell. These analyses provided strong evidence that the carbonate within the bone mineral is not likely being utilized, but instead, the carbonate trapped in a thin layer of water surrounding the bone.

In naturally overwintering anoxic turtles, cold temperatures always precede anoxia. Consequently, we are very interested in knowing if cold acclimation induces changes in turtles that can lead it to become more tolerant to anoxia. Indeed, we showed that when turtles are acclimated to the cold, they accumulate additional buffers in their non-skeletal tissues, which would allow them to accumulate more lactic acid during anoxia and survive longer.

Finally, this award supported several educational outreach activities intended to better understand what leads young people to pursue careers in STEM and whether authentic research experiences improve high school students' understanding of science. During our funding period, we brought 37 high school sophomores and juniors in the lab to conduct a simulated climate change experiment with turtles. From studies of these students, we conclude that high school research experiences may be limited in their ability to improve data interpretation and analysis but may positively impact a student?s understanding of the scientific culture and mutability of scientific facts and theories.
